summaries.body: Italian lawmakers voted to stiffen a legislative decree that olive oil producers and other critics charged would decriminalize olive oil counterfeiting.

display_asset.caption: Donald J. Trump in Palm Beach, Fla., on Tuesday evening.

summaries.body: A revelation that Donald Trump’s family name was once Drumpf caused plenty of buzz, but the change happened long before his ancestors came to the United States.

display_asset.caption: Cycling past a newsstand outside the Beijing office of Nanfang Media Group, which owns Southern Metropolis Daily.

summaries.body: Speculation is rampant on social media in China after the publication of what some saw as a hidden message lamenting the fate of journalists on a newspaper's front page.

display_asset.caption: Smoke billowing as men pulled a tricycle in a neighborhood near a coal-fired power plant in Shanxi Province.

summaries.body: China has released data indicating that it used less coal last year than in 2014, lending support to the view that the country may be reaching a peak in coal consumption.

display_asset.caption: A Facebook innovation hub in Berlin. In an acknowledgment of the growing regulatory challenges confronting Facebook in Europe, Mark Zuckerberg, the chief executive, traveled to Germany last month to meet with policy makers, local publishers and the company’s users.

summaries.body: Facebook became the target of a German competition inquiry on Wednesday into whether the company has abused its dominant position in social networking.

display_asset.caption: Mr. Abrams, who directed the latest “Star Wars” film, spoke at The New York Times’s New Work Summit conference about why the controversy surrounding the Oscars was a signal of the need for systemic change.
display_asset.title: J.J. Abrams on Diversity in Hollywood

summaries.body: J.J. Abrams, who directed the latest “Star Wars” film, spoke about why the controversy surrounding the Oscars was a signal of the need for systemic change.

display_asset.caption: A long-abandoned house at 745 Barbey Street in East New York, Brooklyn, where a skeletal corpse was found Monday on the second floor. The remains were discovered by the new owners.
display_asset.credit: Bryan R. Smith for The New York Times

summaries.body: The skeletal remains of a human body were found in a cluttered, abandoned house in Brooklyn. The medical examiner's office had yet to determine a cause of death.

display_asset.caption: Marvin Gaye, performing at the Royal Albert Hall in 1976.

summaries.body: Marvin Gaye, Elvis Costello and Tom Petty will be among the inductees to the Songwriters Hall of Fame at a ceremony in New York in June.

display_asset.caption: Rebecca Boenigk, the chief and a founder of Neutral Posture, a furniture manufacturer, brought in $7 million last year from government contracts and expects that to double or triple this year.
display_asset.credit: Michael Stravato for The New York Times

summaries.body: The federal government has met a goal set in 1994 of awarding 5 percent of the money it spent on contractors to businesses owned by women.
An essayist describes her complex relationship with the writer James Baldwin, focusing on his experience as an African-American expatriate.
Scott Kelly has landed in Kazakhstan after 340 days in space, the longest such trip by an American astronaut. Scientists will study the health effects of his travel.
A new book proposes replacing high school algebra and calculus with statistics, arguing that the latter will be more useful in civic life.

display_asset.caption: Josh Elliott will be the anchor of the CBSN service.

summaries.body: CBS hired Josh Elliott, who was on "Good Morning America," for a new streaming service, fueling speculation that he might succeed Charlie Rose.
The Tampa Bay Rays will play the Cuban national team in Havana on March 22, Major League Baseball confirmed. President Obama is expected to attend the game.
Erin Andrews, a Fox sportscaster, said in court that a hotel could have prevented a stalker from filming her in the nude. She is seeking $75 million in damages.
Craig Windham, the top-of-the-hour voice of NPR, has died at 66. He was known for delivering bite-size news reports in a warm, familiar tone to millions of Americans.

posts.footer: A New York Times media reporter, via Twitter

summaries.body: Pennsylvania appeals court delays hearing in Bill Cosby criminal case scheduled 4 nxt week. Will decide whether to hear Cosby appeal.

posts.footer: The New York Times’s New Work Summit

display_asset.caption: Richard Plepler, chief executive of HBO, discussed the culture of risk-taking he has tried to foster, and how that played out in “Game of Thrones,” at The New York Times’s New Work Summit.
display_asset.title: Bold Moves Behind ‘Game of Thrones’

summaries.body: HBO's chief executive, Richard Plepler, discussed a business culture of risk-taking, and how that played out in the network's decision to air “Game of Thrones.”

display_asset.caption: Martin E. Hellman, left, and Whitfield Diffie in 1977.

summaries.body: Two cryptography pioneers are set to win the computing world's Turing Award this year. Whitfield Diffie and Martin E. Hellman invented the technology that underpins web commerce.

display_asset.caption: Simon Newman, the former president of Mount St. Mary’s University.
display_asset.credit: Mount St. Mary's University, via Associated Press

summaries.body: A Maryland university president has resigned after he was quoted comparing struggling freshmen to bunnies who should be shot or drowned.

display_asset.caption: Foreign Minister Sergey V. Lavrov of Russia, center, at the European headquarters of the United Nations in Geneva on Tuesday.

summaries.body: Russia’s foreign minister called for negotiations on a new international convention to counter the “extremely urgent” threat of terrorists using chemical weapons.
Britain has unexpectedly dropped the charges against the only remaining suspect in the killing of 29 people in a bombing in Omagh, Northern Ireland, in 1998.
President Obama has awarded the Medal of Honor to a SEAL Team 6 member for his bravery during a mission to rescue an American doctor in Afghanistan.
A Chinese court has upheld a life sentence for a senior aide to Bo Xilai, a former Communist Party official imprisoned for corruption and abuse of power.
A convenience store in Sweden is operating with no employees on the premises. Customers use their phones to unlock the door, and scan their own purchases.

display_asset.caption: The online retailer Souq.com is based in the United Arab Emirates.

summaries.body: Souq.com, a rare e-commerce success story from the Middle East, has raised $275 million from international investors.
Google has confessed that one of its self-driving cars caused an accident early last month. It is the first time the company has said its own car was at fault.

display_asset.caption: A wounded Syrian boy sits on the floor of a make-shift hospital in the rebel-held area of Douma, east of the capital Damascus, following reported air strikes by regime forces on Aug.12, 2015. This photo was credited to Abd Doumany which is a pseudonym used by a Syrian photographer working with AFP.

summaries.body: With a nod to the importance of local coverage, the Pictures of the Year International contest named a 25-year-old Texas woman the year's top newspaper photographer.

display_asset.caption: Capt. Simratpal Singh said he had been targeted because of his religious beliefs.

summaries.body: Capt. Simratpal Singh, a decorated West Point graduate, sued the Defense Department, saying the Army had singled him out for extra tests because of his beard and turban.

display_asset.credit: Stephen B. Morton for The New York Times

summaries.body: A Goldman Sachs employee was put on leave for his ties to the sale of hats that resemble Donald J. Trump’s campaign caps, but with the phrase “Make Christianity Great Again.”
